Urticaria results from dermal oedema (superficial urticaria) or dermo-hypodermal oedema (deep urticaria or angioedema) due to tissue vasodilatation with increased capillary permeability secondary to the release by mast cells of various mediators, the main one being histamine.

Mast cell activation can occur by 2 mechanisms:
- Immunological: via IgE or IgG-type autoantibodies
- Non-immunological: by direct activation of mast cells via different receptors on their surface or by the direct pharmacological action of certain drugs (e.g. NSAIDs).

properties.question: What are the two mechanisms by which mast cell activation can lead to urticaria?
properties.option_a: Immunological activation via IgE antibodies and non-immunological activation via direct histamine release.
properties.option_b: Immunological activation via IgE antibodies and non-immunological activation via direct activation of mast cells using various receptors.
properties.option_c: Immunological activation via IgG-type autoantibodies and non-immunological activation via direct pharmacological action of certain drugs.
properties.option_d: Immunological activation via IgE antibodies and non-immunological activation via direct pharmacological action of certain drugs.
